conclusion: Determine the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) when the wire frame rotates through an angle of 60°.
The induced EMF in the wire frame can be described using Faraday's law of induction.
The maximum induced EMF occurs when the rate of change of the magnetic flux is greatest.
The magnetic flux Φ through the wire frame is given by: Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cos(θ) where A is the area of the wire frame and θ is the angle of rotation.
The area of the wire frame is A = b ⋅ d.
The angular velocity is ω, so the angle of rotation θ as a function of time t is θ = ωt.
The induced EMF E is given by: E = -dΦ/dt.
Substitute Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cos(θ) to get E = B ⋅ A ⋅ sin(θ) ⋅ ω.
The instantaneous value of the induced current I is given by Ohm's law: I = E/R = B ⋅ A ⋅ sin(θ) ⋅ ω/R.
When the wire frame rotates through an angle of 60°, θ = 60° = π/3 radians. Therefore, the instantaneous value of the induced current is I = B ⋅ b ⋅ d ⋅ √3 ⋅ ω/(2R).
The average value of the induced EMF over one complete cycle is given by: E_avg = (1/T) ∫_0^T E dt where T = 2π/ω is the period of the rotation.
The induced EMF as a function of time is: E = B ⋅ A ⋅ sin(θ) ⋅ ω = B ⋅ b ⋅ d ⋅ sin(ωt) ⋅ ω.
The average value of sin(ωt) over one period is zero, leading to E_avg = 0.
The average value of the induced EMF over a half-cycle can be calculated using the formula for the average value of a sine wave over a quarter period.
Calculate E_avg = (2/π) ∫_0^(π/2) B ⋅ b ⋅ d ⋅ sin(ωt) dt = -2B ⋅ b ⋅ d/(π ω).
For the specific angle of 60°, the average value is E_avg = (1/2) E_max = √3/4 B ⋅ b ⋅ d ⋅ ω.
